tips: Understand the company’s mission, values, and recent news.
Review the job description and map your experience to required skills.
Prepare 3–5 thoughtful questions for the interviewer.
Rehearse answers using the STAR method for behavioral questions.
Record yourself answering aloud to refine delivery.
Do mock interviews with peers or mentors.
Dress professionally and arrive early (or log in 5 minutes before virtual interviews).
Maintain eye contact and speak clearly.
Stay calm—even if you’re unsure, think aloud to demonstrate problem-solving.
Send a thank-you email within 24 hours.
Reiterate your interest and mention one specific point from the conversation.
Avoid asking about salary unless they bring it up.

starMethod.title: STAR Method Framework
starMethod.description: Structure your behavioral responses using Situation, Task, Action, Result.

steps.description: Describe the context or challenge you faced.
steps.example: While working at XYZ Corp, our team missed a critical product launch deadline due to misaligned priorities.

steps.description: Explain your specific responsibility in that situation.
steps.example: I was tasked with coordinating between engineering and marketing to realign timelines without compromising quality.

steps.description: Detail the steps you took to address the issue.
steps.example: I organized daily stand-ups, created a shared tracker, and negotiated scope reductions with stakeholders.

steps.description: Share the outcome and quantify impact where possible.
steps.example: We launched two weeks late but received 92% positive customer feedback, leading to a 30% increase in Q3 revenue.

questions: Why are you interested in this role?
What are your strengths and weaknesses?
Where do you see yourself in five years?
Describe a time you handled conflict with a colleague.
Tell me about a project that failed and what you learned.
Give an example of when you went above and beyond.
How do you prioritize tasks when everything seems urgent?
How do you approach debugging a complex system?
Explain a technical concept you’ve taught someone else.
What’s your process for writing testable code?
How would you design a scalable system to handle high traffic?
